channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: These were the most-borrowed books from public libraries in 2024
item.description: Many of the most-borrowed books in 2024, including 'romantasy' titles and memoirs, also appeared on public library lists in 2023.
item.content:encoded:
Many of the most-borrowed books in 2024, including 'romantasy' titles and memoirs, also appeared on public library lists in 2023.

(Image credit: Magali Cohen)
item.dc:creator: Neda Ulaby

item.title: Jimmy Carter gave Panama control of the canal. It's one of his most controversial achievements
item.description: Handing control of the Panama Canal from the U.S. over to the Central American country was one of President Jimmy Carter's most controversial, and most overshadowed, foreign policy achievements.
item.content:encoded: Handing control of the Panama Canal from the U.S. over to the Central American country was one of President Jimmy Carter's most controversial, and most overshadowed, foreign policy achievements.
item.dc:creator: Rolando Arrieta

item.title: A look back at Jimmy Carter's presidency
item.description: Former President Jimmy Carter served as president of the United States from 1977 to 1981, with a focus on human rights-centered policies.
item.content:encoded:
Former President Jimmy Carter served as president of the United States from 1977 to 1981, with a focus on human rights-centered policies.

(Image credit: Bettmann)
item.dc:creator: Virginia Lozano

item.title: Carter's single White House term still stirs controversy after more than 40 years
item.description: Jimmy Carter was a former one-term governor from Georgia, almost unknown nationally, when he broke through in Iowa and New Hampshire early in 1976 and rode that momentum all the way to Washington.
item.content:encoded:
Jimmy Carter was a former one-term governor from Georgia, almost unknown nationally, when he broke through in Iowa and New Hampshire early in 1976 and rode that momentum all the way to Washington.

(Image credit: Hulton Archive)
item.dc:creator: Ron Elving

item.title: 2 men were found dead from exposure after looking for Sasquatch
item.description: The bodies of two men looking for Sasquatch were found in a forest in Washington state after a three-day search.
item.content:encoded:
The bodies of two men looking for Sasquatch were found in a forest in Washington state after a three-day search.

(Image credit: Skamania County Sheriff's Office)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: Jimmy Carter, former U.S. president and peace activist, dies at 100
item.description: Carter was president from 1977 to 1981, but he was perhaps more famous for the life he led after he left office. He was one of the biggest advocates for peace, democracy and human rights.
item.content:encoded:
Carter was president from 1977 to 1981, but he was perhaps more famous for the life he led after he left office. He was one of the biggest advocates for peace, democracy and human rights.

(Image credit: John Amis)
item.dc:creator: Kathy Lohr

item.title: He left everything to flee war in Syria. What does the war's end mean for his future?
item.description:
When Syria's dictatorship fell in early December, celebrations broke out around the world - including nearly 6,000 miles away, in Toledo, Ohio.

That's where Mohammed al-Refai, a refugee from Syria, lives now. NPR has followed his story for nearly a decade.

In 2015, millions of Syrians fled the civil war in their country. al-Refai got a visa to come to the U.S. His parents and siblings, who fled to Jordan, did not. So, he moved on his own to Toledo, where built a new life for himself.

He long dreamed of visiting his family and maybe, one day, returning to Syria.

With the Syrian civil war now over, we talked to al-Refai about what comes next.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
When Syria's dictatorship fell in early December, celebrations broke out around the world - including nearly 6,000 miles away, in Toledo, Ohio.

That's where Mohammed al-Refai, a refugee from Syria, lives now. NPR has followed his story for nearly a decade.

In 2015, millions of Syrians fled the civil war in their country. al-Refai got a visa to come to the U.S. His parents and siblings, who fled to Jordan, did not. So, he moved on his own to Toledo, where built a new life for himself.

He long dreamed of visiting his family and maybe, one day, returning to Syria.

With the Syrian civil war now over, we talked to al-Refai about what comes next.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

item.title: Stories that gave us joy (and a new workout routine) in 2024
item.description: In a year where there was a plethora of bad news around the world — climate, conflict and more — there were moments of joy in our global coverage. Take a look!
item.content:encoded:
In a year where there was a plethora of bad news around the world — climate, conflict and more — there were moments of joy in our global coverage. Take a look!

(Image credit: Clockwise from upper left: Andy Rementer for NPR; Viraj Nayer for NPR; Ben de la Cruz/NPR; Gustavo Minas for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Marc Silver

item.title: Azerbaijan's president says crashed jetliner was shot down by Russia unintentionally
item.description: Azerbaijan's President Ilham Aliyev said that the Azerbaijani airliner that crashed last week was shot down by Russia unintentionally, and criticized Moscow for trying to "hush up" the issue for days.
item.content:encoded:
Azerbaijan's President Ilham Aliyev said that the Azerbaijani airliner that crashed last week was shot down by Russia unintentionally, and criticized Moscow for trying to "hush up" the issue for days.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Under a 'grandma moon,' Native Americans honor their sacred pact with salmon
item.description: Native American New Year was celebrated on the solstice under a canopy of winter stars. Near a crackling bonfire, the Nisqually tribe shared their culture and renewed their sacred pact with the salmon.
item.content:encoded:
Native American New Year was celebrated on the solstice under a canopy of winter stars. Near a crackling bonfire, the Nisqually tribe shared their culture and renewed their sacred pact with the salmon.

(Image credit: Annie Warren)
item.dc:creator: Anna King
